Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Performance Evaluation of Intra-domain Bandwidth Allocation and Inter-domain Routing Algorithms for a QoS-guaranteed Routing Path Discovery

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the fundamental issue of dynamic bandwidth provisioning services is investigated. The goal is to gain a better understanding of the theoretical aspects of multi-domain routing and to develop novel techniques that will substantially improve the performance of multi-domain networks. The proposed solutions will assist in the successful deployment of computer services across multi-domain networks. In particular, this project will develop novel algorithms for QoS-guaranteed routing. The goal is to evaluate those algorithms through use of multiple kinds of GENI resources.

The obtained results will be expected to generate a strong interest in the network community at large for QoS-guaranteed routing in multi-domain networks. They will also generate significant impacts on computer network research through a better understanding of the theoretical issues of multi-domain routing for the design of future Internet architectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the fundamental issue of dynamic bandwidth provisioning services has been investigated. The goal of this project was to gain a better understanding of the theoretical aspects of multi-domain routing and to develop novel techniques that might substantially improve the performance of multi-domain networks. For this purpose, the measurement techniques and tools for the end-to-end performance of computing services have been developed and the routing path selection algorithms for the performance optimization of computing services have been evaluated. The solutions consisting of those techniques, tools, and algorithms have been implemented and evaluated using different computing resources on the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) that comprises InstaGENI and ExoGENI at about 90 resource sites across the United State. The results of this project will assist in the successful deployment of computer services across multi-domain networks for Quality of Service (QoS)-guaranteed. Furthermore, the research experiments have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate curriculums where lab experiments have been developed for multiple computer science courses. Moreover, more than five graduate students have graduated. More than 10 published papers and 15 conference posters with demos have also been generated from this project.

As expected, the obtained results of this project will generate a strong interest in the network community at large for QoS-guaranteed routing in multi-domain networks. They will not only generate significant impacts on computer network research through a better understanding of the theoretical issues of multi-domain routing for the design of future Internet architectures but also make significant impacts on teaching and student research.
